contentfulWebBlogPost.title: Which savings account is best for a lump sum of money?

description.description: It's important to consider all the options of savings accounts when it comes to what you should do with a lump sum of money.

content.value: What can you do with a lump sum of money?

At some point you might find yourself figuring out what's best to do with aÂ lump sumÂ of money. This could be because you've sold your house or you've had your money in aÂ fixed rate bondÂ which is due to mature soon. Either way, it's important to consider all the options when it comes to what you should do with it.
You can put aÂ lump sumÂ of money in aÂ savings account

Finding aÂ savings accountÂ where your money can earn interest is the best place to start. It's always important to compare theÂ Annual Equivalent RateÂ (AER) when choosing whichÂ savings accountÂ is best for you.Â You can also try Money Saving Expert's lump sum

There are
four main types of savings accounts,
but here are the most popular savings accounts for lump sums of money:
A fixedÂ rateÂ savingsÂ accountÂ orÂ fixed rate bondÂ
If you're looking to put away your money for a setÂ period of time, a fixedÂ rateÂ savingsÂ accountÂ orÂ fixed rate bondÂ could be best for you.Â

Your money is locked away for a certain period and the interest rate is fixed. A fixedÂ rate accountÂ usually earns you more interest than anÂ easy access account. Return is guaranteed but withdrawals aren't usually allowed so this doesn't always suit everyone.

The best fixedÂ rateÂ savingsÂ accountÂ for you will depend on how long you want to leave your money untouched for. The longer you can leave your money, the higher theÂ interest rateÂ you earn will be!
An easy access savings account

An easy accessÂ savings accountÂ is useful if you're considering moving money intoÂ longer-termÂ investments or if you're looking to be more flexible with the money you have. You have the flexibility to withdraw money when you need to.
An easy accessÂ savings accountÂ usually has a higherÂ interest rateÂ than manyÂ current accounts, however a fixedÂ rateÂ savingsÂ accountÂ will still probably give you theÂ bestÂ rateÂ of interest.
AÂ cash ISA
If you're a bigÂ saver, you might find that putting aÂ lump sumÂ amount into aÂ cash ISAÂ is the most effective way to manage your money.

AÂ cash ISAÂ is aÂ savings accountÂ where interest isn't taxed. If you're over the age of 16 in the UK, you can put up to Â£20,000 in an ISA each year and once it's in it staysÂ tax-free. You can now get tax-free savings through your Monzo account too. To find out more, read about
getting an ISA with Monzo here.
You can also take money out of a fixed rateÂ cash ISA, although there might be penalties which means you lose interest.
You can invest aÂ lump sumÂ of money

Some people decide to invest their money depending on how they feel about risk. Investing into theÂ stock marketÂ means that your money can potentially see high growth. But yourÂ lump sumÂ would also be exposed to any potential downward movements too!
How to make sure yourÂ lump sumÂ of money is safe

The money you deposit is protected up to a total of Â£85,000 by the FSCS. Please note, this means if you have separate accounts with our savings providers outside of the Monzo app, then the deposits held in those accounts will also count towards the limit of Â£85,000.
